title: Effects of Glossolalia
text:
Abstract
Some Christians speak in tongues. This study uses data from the Pew Research Center 2014 Religious Landscape Study to examine the effect of glossolalia on a variety of religious, social, and political attitudes and behavior.

title: Background
text:
Research Questions
In this study, I use data from a recent national survey to explore the practice of glossolalia in the population of American adults. I pose the following research questions:

title: Background
text:
Who speaks in tongues? Which traditions? Which demographics?
Correlates of glossolalia. What religious variables are most predictive of glossolalia? Is there something special about speaking in tongues?
Effects of glossolalia on attitudes, psychology well-being?

title: Methods
text:
Data Source
The data for this project come from the 2014 Religious Landscape Study, by the Pew Research Center.

title: Methods
text:
Instruments

Outcome variables


Predictor variables
Frequency of praying or speaking in tongues. Measurement of glossolalia comes from one item in the Religious Landscape Survey. Respondents how identified with one of the following Christian traditions – Evangelical Protestant Tradition, Mainline Protestant Tradition, Historically Black Protestant Tradition, Catholic, Mormon, Orthodox Christian, Jehovah’s Witness, Other Christian – were asked how often they “speak or pray in tongues” with the following response options: at least once a week, once or twice a month, several times a year, seldom, or never.

title: Methods
text:
Statistical Analysis
To investigate the prevalance of glossolalia in the Christian world I used basic descriptive statistics. To isolate the effect of glossolalia on attitudes I used OLS regression.
